description: From Middle English scof, skof, probably of North Germanic origin. Compare Old Norse skaup, Old Danish skof, Old Frisian skof (“insult, shame”), and Old High German scoph.

entries.meaning: A derisive or mocking expression of scorn, contempt, or reproach.
examples: Synonyms: derision, ridicule; see also Thesaurus:ridicule

entries.meaning: An object of scorn, mockery, or derision.

verbs.description: scoff (third-person singular simple present scoffs, present participle scoffing, simple past and past participle scoffed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To jeer; to laugh with contempt and derision.
(transitive) To mock; to treat with scorn.

description: A variant, attested since the mid 19th century, of scaff, of uncertain origin. Compare scarf (“eat quickly”).

entries.meaning: (Newfoundland, South Africa and British Army slang) Food.

examples: Lunch for the busy has become a quick scoff of processed, terrifyingly orange couscous,  […]

verbs.description: scoff (third-person singular simple present scoffs, present participle scoffing, simple past and past participle scoffed)

entries.meaning: (Britain, Newfoundland, slang) To eat food quickly.
(Newfoundland, South Africa and British Army slang) To eat.
